docs.abstract: The social media site had been blocked after it deleted a post from President Muhammadu Buhari about secessionist groups that was widely seen as threatening.
docs.snippet: The social media site had been blocked after it deleted a post from President Muhammadu Buhari about secessionist groups that was widely seen as threatening.
docs.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The Nigerian government restored access in the country to Twitter on Thursday after a seven-month suspension that was imposed after the social media site deleted a post by Nigeria’s president that threatened a violent crackdown on secessionist groups.

headline.print_headline: Twitter Restored in Nigeria After 7-Month Ban for Deleting President’s Post

docs.abstract: Residents in a divided predominantly white town in upstate New York are fighting a state ruling to remove the Native American mascot.
docs.snippet: Residents in a divided predominantly white town in upstate New York are fighting a state ruling to remove the Native American mascot.
docs.lead_paragraph: Cory and Sarah McMillan of Cambridge, N.Y., recoiled when their 6-year-old daughter came home from her first-grade class one day and mentioned that she and her friend were playing “like animals” in a game they called “Savages.”

headline.main: Facing a Ban, a School District Fights to Keep ‘Indian’ Nickname
headline.print_headline: Bitter Divisions Surround Fight to Defy ‘Indian’ Mascot Ban

docs.abstract: Progressive philanthropists who fund groups that promote extreme views are “exacerbating intraparty conflict and stoking interparty backlash.”
docs.snippet: Progressive philanthropists who fund groups that promote extreme views are “exacerbating intraparty conflict and stoking interparty backlash.”
docs.lead_paragraph: The killing of George Floyd and the nationwide Black Lives Matter protests that followed drove an exceptionally large increase in foundation grants and pledges to criminal and racial justice reform groups and other causes, ranging from the United Negro College Fund to the Center for Antiracist Research and from the National Museum of African American History to the Yes 4 Minneapolis campaign to dismantle the Minneapolis Police Department.

headline.main: The Law of Unintended Political Consequences Strikes Again

docs.abstract: For many officers, their bodies, minds and lives will never be the same after the attack.
docs.snippet: For many officers, their bodies, minds and lives will never be the same after the attack.
docs.lead_paragraph: On the morning of Jan. 6, Caroline Edwards, a 31-year-old United States Capitol Police officer, was stationed by some stairs on the Capitol grounds when the energy of the crowd in front of her seemed to take on a different shape; it was like that moment when rain suddenly becomes hail. A loud, sour-sounding horn bleated, piercing through the noise of the crowd, whose cries coalesced into an accusatory chant: “U.S.A.! U.S.A.!” Edwards, who is 5-foot-4, tried to make herself look imposing. Behind a row of bike racks, alongside four other officers, she stood in a wide stance, her hands on her hips. A man in front of her whipped off his jacket as if he were getting ready for something, flipped his red MAGA hat backward — and then the rioters were pushing the bike racks forward as the officers pushed back, trying to hold their balance.

headline.main: The Capitol Police and the Scars of Jan. 6

keywords.name: persons
keywords.value: Evans, William F (US Capitol Police Officer)

byline.original: By Susan Dominus and Luke Broadwater

docs.abstract: Also, Bevy Smith and Marina Rust share where they have hunkered down this winter.
docs.snippet: Also, Bevy Smith and Marina Rust share where they have hunkered down this winter.
docs.lead_paragraph: After a cautious fall social season, the New York charity circuit went into hiatus in December because of the Omicron surge. Here is how some philanthropists and society figures spent the past month.

headline.main: How Prabal Gurung Plans to Fall in Love This Year
headline.print_headline: Maybe It’s Time to Fall in Love

docs.abstract: We’ve ceded too much control over our speech to Big Tech.
docs.snippet: We’ve ceded too much control over our speech to Big Tech.
docs.lead_paragraph: This past weekend, when Twitter permanently suspended the personal account of Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican of Georgia, her offenses were clear: She had repeatedly posted misinformation about Covid and vaccines, violating Twitter’s rules.

headline.main: Let Marjorie Taylor Greene Keep Her Social Media Accounts

docs.abstract: The annual March for Life rally is taking on a celebratory tone this year as participants expect the Supreme Court to overturn Roe v. Wade.
docs.snippet: The annual March for Life rally is taking on a celebratory tone this year as participants expect the Supreme Court to overturn Roe v. Wade.
docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-abortion protesters descended on Washington from across the country on Friday for the annual March for Life, a ritual that this year took on a tone of hopeful celebration as they anticipated the Supreme Court overturning the decision that established a constitutional right to abortion half a century ago.

headline.main: Anti-Abortion Marchers Gather With an Eye on the Supreme Court
headline.print_headline: With Roe v. Wade Teetering, Marchers Strike a Celebratory Tone

byline.original: By Kate Zernike and Madeleine Ngo

docs.abstract: The composer John Adams reviews a new book by Jed Perl, “Authority and Freedom: A Defense of the Arts.”
docs.snippet: The composer John Adams reviews a new book by Jed Perl, “Authority and Freedom: A Defense of the Arts.”
docs.lead_paragraph: AUTHORITY AND FREEDOMA Defense of the ArtsBy Jed Perl

headline.main: Does Art Have to Be Relevant? One Prominent Critic Says No.

docs.abstract: He was famous for his larger-than-life persona, but a lesser-known fact was that he took a select few under his wing and guided their careers.
docs.snippet: He was famous for his larger-than-life persona, but a lesser-known fact was that he took a select few under his wing and guided their careers.
docs.lead_paragraph: “He was my first real mentor,” said Dario Calmese, a photographer and fashion consultant, referring to André Leon Talley, the former Vogue editor who died on Monday,

headline.main: André Leon Talley: Mentor in Chief
headline.print_headline: Under His Wing, a Select Few Flourished

docs.abstract: In “Phenotypes,” by Paulo Scott, a man who has spent his career examining thorny issues of race returns home to confront a quandary of his own.
docs.snippet: In “Phenotypes,” by Paulo Scott, a man who has spent his career examining thorny issues of race returns home to confront a quandary of his own.
docs.lead_paragraph: PHENOTYPESBy Paulo ScottTranslated by Daniel Hahn

headline.main: A Novel Punctures the Fantasy of Post-Racial Society
